evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and consistently observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t0_prelim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains a valid root cause despite potential alternative explanations or confounding factors in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_baseline_t0_prelim.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as misaligned task execution, delayed information sharing, and unclear role responsibilities in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_baseline_t0_prelim.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident and consistently observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t0_prelim scope.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP despite communication indicates coordination failure
The presence of communication does not imply effective coordination
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If procedural deviations or environmental deficiencies better explained the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators but also a failure to stop at the TRP, indicating coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or marking deficiency, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the pushback error was due to communication breakdown or procedural/environmental factors

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as misaligned task execution, delayed information sharing, and unclear role responsibilities in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_baseline_t0_prelim.

assumptions: The described crew interactions reflect communication and coordination quality.
The continued movement beyond TRP indicates delayed or unclear role responsibilities or information sharing.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and aligned task execution without role confusion or delays.
If the incident was primarily caused by environmental or marking deficiencies rather than crew coordination.

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show misaligned task execution and role responsibility issues (trainee stopping and instructor taking over), while H4 shows delayed or unclear information/action leading to the aircraft overrunning the TRP, supporting communication/coordination breakdown key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent to which communication breakdown versus procedural deviation contributed to the event.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains a valid root cause despite potential alternative explanations or confounding factors in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_baseline_t0_prelim.

assumptions: The communication described was insufficient to prevent the incident, indicating breakdown despite attempts.
No other unreported factors fully explain the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination with no errors, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event without coordination issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, yet the aircraft still overran the TRP and hit a barrier, supporting that communication/coordination breakdown remains a valid root cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or environment factors contributed more significantly than communication breakdown.
